subtitle: I'm happy to announce that March 1st is the official release date of the New Thinking
Allowed magazine's first quarterly issue.
You can download free PDF copies from the
website of the New Thinking Allowed Foundation.
If you like a high quality printed edition as a
collectible, you can order it from magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be exploring consciousness in the
cosmos with me is cosmologist Jude Currivan,
who is the author of The Cosmic Hologram.
She is also co-author with Irvin Laszlo of a book called Cosmos.
Some of her other titles include The Eighth Chakra, The Wave, and The Thirteenth Step.
Welcome Jude.
Thank you, Jeff.
It's a pleasure to be with you once again.
You are somewhat unique amongst the cosmologists
that I know, because you have a serious interest
in parapsychology.
Well, it's not an interest, it's an experience.
I've experienced what I call supernormal phenomena since I was very small.
For me, they're not supernatural, they're not
paranormal, they're supernormal attributes
of phenomena that we all innately have.
In other words, from your perspective, consciousness
pervades the whole universe, the whole cosmos,
and perhaps beyond.
I'm not sure there is a beyond to the cosmos
in the sense that at its biggest form, the
cosmos is all there is, has ever been, will be.
But that sense of an infinite and eternal
cosmic mind, as Einstein called it, of which
universes, our universe as one, are finite
thought forms, and we are microcosmic co-creators
of its realities.
You do use the term, I think you call it, the cosmic plenum?
Yeah, plenum is a sort of sense of what lies beyond what we call space-time.
So space-time, energy-matter space-time, our
universe is an emergent phenomenon of consciousness.
So what lies outside space-time is what I'm calling the cosmic plenum, but essentially
it's the mind of God, it's the cosmic mind.
And you use that term in a way that suggests familiarity.
Yeah, probably, as you're grinning, and I think Riley took to grin.
I've experienced multidimensional realities all my life, well, since I was four years
old and been aware of them.
So from that age, I've experienced precognition,
telepathy, out-of-body experiences, many other...
I've walked between worlds, essentially,
all my life, and I've communicated with many
discarnate intelligences, as well as obviously many incarnate wisdom keepers.
So it's very much been that exploration of
the nature of reality itself that's been alive
until now.
What's your feeling?
Most of the scientists I interview who have had these experiences are quite hesitant to
speak of them so openly.
Well, in our age especially, I'm quite a private
person, but if I'm to be in service to what
I'm calling the whole world view, and the understanding of that, and the experiencing
that, the embodying of that unity awareness,
then I just feel I need to be transparent,
and there's nothing hidden, and if people disagree, that's fine, but I'm not hiding
anything in that sense.
Well, in addition to being open and to being
a fine theorist, and I encourage our viewers
to look at some of the previous interviews we've done, you have made a point of going
through the academic literature to find support
for your ideas, and as well for the supernormal
experiences of consciousness that you've had.
Oh, very much so.
I really seek to bring that sort of understanding
together with the experience, and so absolutely,
and certainly in my latest book, The Cosmic
Hologram, I cite something like 140 academically
peer-reviewed papers from something like 500
researchers, not just in physics, but across
many, many different fields of research to
bring together the evidence and the emerging
evidence for this whole world view of the Cosmic Hologram.
Well, and our viewers will know that I have a
background in parapsychology, which is something
of an orphan science in a way that it's a legitimate science, but it's on the very
fringe, and there are certainly many, many people
in mainstream physics, biology, psychology,
who feel that parapsychology doesn't exist, or at least it ought not to exist, but you
have gone out of your way to include parapsychological
research among the other studies that you
cite, and I think you go even further to suggest
that it has a real function, a real place
in the cosmos of your understanding.
Well, very much.
I think, first of all, to say these aren't just my ideas, what I'm bringing together,
and there are some, you know, perhaps I've gone further and brought it all together in
a synthesis that hasn't been done as yet by
others, but it's coming, because this is the
direction of travel, and unfortunately, fortunately,
20th century science gave us a major move
forward in our understanding of reality by describing our universe in terms of energy,
matter, space, time, but it didn't go far enough,
because first of all, it didn't understand,
and at that point, I understand why it didn't,
the significance of information, and secondly,
it peripheralized and took out the nature of
consciousness, and for me as a cosmologist,
this is about the whole, if we can't understand
consciousness, if we can't, you know, embody
that in a perspective of the nature of reality,
we don't have, you know, an understanding
of reality, and what's beautiful now is that
the evidence is growing exponentially to reveal
that all we call reality is essentially unified,
that mind is matter and consciousness isn't
something we have or something that's just
evolved, it's literally what we and the whole
world are.
One might say that you are a panpsychist.
Yes, if you, yeah, I'm not great on labels and even the word cosmologist, but yes, in
the sense that that's been not just my experience
all my life, but it's now very much that leading
edge science across many fields of research
and all scales of existence is coming to that
same perspective of the nature of reality.
Now I know lots of skeptics of that point of
view, and when you say you're a panpsychist,
the first thing they're likely to do is point
to an object like this and say, you mean that's
conscious?
For me, consciousness is a very broad church,
yeah, it really is, and one of the reasons
I didn't subtitle my book Consciousness at the
Centre of Creation, but subtitled it Information
at the Centre of Creation, is that I'm very
happy for us all to have a lovely discussion,
debate and exploration of consciousness, self-awareness,
different levels of it, but for me at the
moment within our human perspective and perception,
I feel it's important that we can get over
the bridge from the duality-based appearance
of reality to its true unified nature, and
then we can have a lovely discussion and much deeper
dive into what we understand as consciousness.
Let's talk about the brain.
The brain certainly seems to play a very unique role in human consciousness.
Conventionally it's suggested that the brain
creates consciousness sort of the way the
stomach creates digestion.
How do you view it?
Well, for me, all that we call reality is consciousness at many different levels of
self-awareness and embodiment.
The idea, of course, mind arises from matter,
but what we know now is that first of all
what we call matter is incredibly ephemeral and will-of-the-wisp when we drill down to
subatomic scales, and at the same time we now
have the proof, the evidence, that information
is as real as anything we call material.
So those two are converging in a really powerful
way to start to restate the nature of our
physicalized experience in our universe, not
in terms of energy matter and space-time,
but they are emergent phenomena of information,
of consciousness expressing itself as information
and information expressing itself in complementary ways.
So the understanding of our universe as emergent
appearance from these deeper realms of reality,
when we do that we then realize not only that
information is reality, but that mind is matter
and matter is mind.
And it's interesting that a lot of doctors
and psychologists are actually realizing this.
I'm talking to quite a few neurosurgeons who
are saying this too, that that question for
them is just the wrong question, that they absolutely understand that mind is matter.
And so our brain is essentially is a moderator,
a modulator, a transceiver of consciousness,
but it is of itself consciousness, it is itself
information, not energy matter and space-time.
In other words, one might think of the brain
as akin to, I'm going to say, a living radio.
Yeah, but what's living?
You know, we can actually extend the definition
of living to our entire universe, you know,
if we go beyond the very limited biological perceptions of this.
So you ask about the statue, the statue is informed, it is part of reality.
Everything is integrally reality and all reality
is informed, holographically manifest and
is essentially consciousness, cosmic consciousness.
Would you say with regard to this lovely work
of art that it's in some way different now
that it's been sculpted than it was when it was just a stone in a mountain somewhere?
In a way, yes, because if we see everything as
informed, it has more complexity and therefore
it has a greater level of informational entropy
or informational content than it did when
it was part of the mountain, because its informational
content now connects it with the sculptor,
with the intention of the sculptor, with the
form, with our interactions with it, with
our viewers' interactions with it.
So our universe as it exists and evolves as
a unified entity, first of all, every moment
of time flowing forward, our universe embodies
more and more informational content and therefore
conscious experience.
And so whenever that beautiful sculpture was
actually part of a mountain, you know, of
itself, if it was still part of the mountain,
our universe would have moved on, but it has
moved on specifically through the co-creativity of the sculptor.
There's an art form referred to as psychometry,
where a person with certain supernormal abilities
would be able to read into this its own history,
a clairvoyant or a psychometrist would be
able to tell me about the people who sculpted
this and maybe even tell me about the people
who mined this stone itself, that they've left
mental impressions that are somehow captured
here in the stone.
Well, it's all informational and I would say that we all have supernormal abilities.
It's just that our culture closes them down so early that it's only a few folks who are
particularly sensitive or particularly rebellious
that can go through and continue to have those
supernormal abilities.
But we all have them.
It's part of our intrinsic nature and our
intrinsic nature is as a microcosmic co-creative
consciousness of our entire universe.
So yes, to psychometrize the information, because with each moment as space expands
and time flows, not only does our universe embody more and more information, but that
information is never lost.
So we have that past information of the universe knowing itself in every moment.
Supernormal abilities, including psychometry,
can tap into that past incremental accumulation
of information.
When you say the information is never lost, some people may be shocked.
Some people would probably hope that some information would get lost.
Please lose it.
Freud, for example, said, we don't want to know what's in our own mind.
That may be the case.
It doesn't mean it's lost.
It can be mislaid, it can be suppressed, it can be put at the back, it can whatever.
But physicists have a real issue if it was
lost, because quantum mechanics and the laws
of physics absolutely rely on the fact that information is not lost.
And you're speaking as a scientist.
I am speaking as a scientist, absolutely.
When you say that, that the conservation of matter and energy applies to information
as well.
It's more than the conservation of energy matter, it's the fact that the second law
of thermodynamics, when we restate it as the
second law of infodynamics, and entropy as
being the informational content of a system,
entropy, informational entropy always increases.
So throughout our entire universe, from the
beginning, within space-time, as an attribute
of space-time, information is not lost.
Your colleague, Ervin Laszlo, refers to the Akashic field, or the Akashic records, as
the embodiment of all information.
Indeed.
And Ervin very much describes, you know, the
universe in the same way that I do, as being
informed and holographically manifest.
So for him, he's just using a different terminology
to describe this accumulation of information
that is accessible because we're innately part of our universe.
So you know, I have a background in criminology we were discussing earlier.
Indeed.
In a sense, it would mean that every crime that's ever committed could, in principle,
be solved.
Indeed.
Indeed.
Everything that manifests within space-time essentially has an informational signature
and an informational story.
And I sometimes wonder if the human cultural
need or felt need to suppress these levels
of consciousness is sort of an effort, a primordial effort, to cover up crime.
Oh, gracious.
I've never thought of it in those terms.
My sense is it's even more generic than that.
You know, if...I talk about actors, okay,
and actors tend to fall into two categories.
There's the method actor, right, that really
delves deep into, becomes the role, okay.
And there's the other type of actor that always knows they're playing a role.
And it seems that when we come into human form, into human incarnation, a lot of us
become method actors and really identify ourselves
with this role and this body and this position.
This perspective.
And others are sort of more perceiving that we
are spiritual beings having a human experience.
And it feels to me important that we do go
some way to aligning ourselves with this role.
That's what we came to do.
That's what we came to be, perhaps to learn, to experience, to grow.
So you know, just having this sense of we
are spiritual beings and we are human beings.
And so that balance between being here and
being now and being grounded in physical reality
means that in a way a level of not knowingness,
a level of perhaps encapsulating our humanness
is really important in being human and yet
not forgetting that we have that connection.
Well sometimes when I go to the theatre I get so caught up in an emotion picture that
it's as if I'm in the movie, I forget that I'm sitting in the theatre.
I know.
My husband says, because if it's something
like Star Wars, which I love all, I'm grabbing
his hand so tight, you know, it's get off, I'm absolutely in there.
And that's fine when it's a film and that's fine
to some degree, but when our human experience
persuades us of the separation between us and perhaps the fears that come from that
perceived separation and the conflicts that
come from that separation and the dysfunctional
behaviours that come from that separation, then I feel it's time for us, as I feel we
are now, to remember who we really are, that we
are spiritual beings, microcosmic co-creators
of our realities, having a human experience.
And that term co-creator, it's something of a
buzzword, but I know you mean it very seriously.
Very seriously.
As a responsibility that we now have based on the evolution of science and culture to
the point where we have a grasp on how we can
really begin to, as a species, take control
of our own future evolution.
Absolutely.
And, you know, I don't want to be heavy with
the idea of responsibility because I feel
this is a lovely song and an invitation to do
this and to step forward into understanding,
experiencing, and embody the unity awareness
of unified reality, which is where, as you
say, all the science is coming towards that
reconciles with spiritual, universal spiritual
experiences, and it's incredibly empowering.
Because unity awareness doesn't mean this sort of homogeneity.
When we do this, when we actually get to this
understanding, we realize how unified reality
has differentiated itself into this glorious universe, this beautiful planet.
Each of us are unique, and yet collectively,
however diverse we are, we have this wonderful
commonality of being part of a human family.
We have this amazing, abundant planet, how beautiful she is.
And so, as we remember that unity, we can celebrate the diversity, we can empower the
unique me-ness, and come the me and the we,
and my goodness, where is that going to take
us?
We are so excited by the potential and the
possibility of how remembering and embodying
unity awareness.
We're like kids, you know, we're like, oh my goodness, where is this going to take us
as our next step of conscious evolution?
Well, when you ask the question, where is
that going to take us, I know there are many
visions of Alpha and the Omega that we're heading toward a future of some sort, and
it makes me wonder about precognition, a
topic we've discussed, precognition and time.
We've talked about time in an earlier interview
as being related to Boltzmann's law of entropy.
Yes, but as informational content of our entire
universe, so as our entire universe evolves,
time flows because the flow of time itself is that increase of informational content
every moment of our universe's existence and evolution.
You earlier, you described a wonderful metaphor
for thinking about precognition as the advance
wave of coming from the prow of a ship as it moves through the ocean.
Yeah, you know, if you see a ship moving across
a lake or an ocean, at the front of the ship
there's a sort of a bow wave, and it's rather
like a sort of a just forming, you know, before
then the ship moves through it.
And it seems the best sort of evidence that
I can put together as an explanation for both
precognition, which a lot of evidence supports,
is that as our universe moves forward, at
that point of the nowness of it, there is a
bow wave beyond that where reality, physical
reality is not yet crystallized into the now,
but its possibilities and potentialities are
doing so.
So that's how I perceive the precognition, but also it's an understanding perhaps how
consciousness comes into its manifestation, because we talked in an earlier interview
about how non-physicalized attractors of consciousness
actually form boundary systems, whether it's
of an ecosystem or indeed of our collective psyche, and we talked about conflicts and
how there's an attractor base perhaps of our
separation or perceived separation that gives
rise to fear-based behaviors of which conflicts
is one manifestation, and how we can co-create
an attractor of peace and a co-tractor of love.
And when complex systems are at the point of unsustainability, their attractor basins
become, you know, start to fall, the boundaries
start to decohere, okay, and what happens
is there's a possibility of either falling into disorder and chaos or creating a move
into a high level of coherence, yeah, and it
seems to me that in our collective consciousness
at the moment, that attractor of our perceived
separation, you know, of the world, how we
see it, how we experience it from that fragmented understanding is falling away.
Our boundaries are, you know, falling away, our behaviors are unsustainable, how we are
in the world is unsustainable.
At the same time, in this bow wave of potentiality,
there's a higher level of coherence being
formed, and what happens in complex systems is
something called flickering, and what happens
is that consciousness is sort of trying to
move to this higher level of coherence, whether
it's an ecosystem or whether it's our collective psyche, and then it falls back.
So it's almost like we're potentializing this
higher level of coherence of the understanding
and experiencing, embodying unity awareness,
but the old paradigm is still pulling us back.
But when the flickering is getting stronger,
as more and more people are potentializing
this, we're moving forward.
What an elegant description.
I get the impression, and perhaps I'm completely
off base here, but it seems as if this beautiful
description in your hand language is amazing
in and of itself, I hope our viewers will
pay attention to that, but I get the impression
you're describing what mathematicians sometimes
think of in catastrophe theory.
They do, but they're really describing it
more now in terms of complexity, because when
there is an emergence of, for example, a biological
entity, when that emergence happens, that
entity moves from a level of complexity and coherence to a higher level of coherence,
whether it's a single cell to a multi-cell
being, whether it's an organelle to an organ,
whether it's a sort of a very simple ecosystem to a more complex ecosystem.
Calamity embodies higher levels of coherence.
Now what happens is there could be a situation
at that point where a calamity happens.
So for example, 65 million years ago, the
ecosystem of Gaia had got to a level of complexity,
and then an asteroid came in and destroyed a great deal of the biological ecosystem.
Wiped out the dinosaurs that were once very prevalent right here in Nevada.
As you know, because you were the discoverer
of the first dinosaur footprints in Nevada,
which is so cool.
I was with two of my friends, and that's true.
We did.
That's so cool.
But the thing is, when that catastrophe happened,
the little creatures who are ancestors, our
mammalian ancestors, there was an opportunity
for Gaia to then develop a higher level of
coherence.
So yes, there was a catastrophe, but from that catastrophe, there were still seeds of
possibility.
Tiny little mammals, probably smaller than mice.
Yeah.
That then became all of the mammals that we have on our earth now.
So even when there is that falling, there is nonetheless, unless the entirety of our
planetary biosphere was wiped out, there's
always that possibility consciousness, life,
will find a way.
And so what happens is, yes, there can be a calamity, but it doesn't always have to
be a catastrophe.
And often a biological emergence can go from
that level of complexity to that level of
higher level of coherence without a catastrophe.
The question is, what's going to happen with us?
Because if we don't do that, the chances are we'll do that.
Well, you seem to identify not just with your
own human embodiment, but I get a sense that
you feel comfortable identifying with those tiny little mammals and maybe even earlier
life forms as well.
Am I correct?
Oh, much more than that.
For me, life is the cosmos.
It's far beyond biological existence.
And you talked about communication with conscious, disembodied beings.
Yes.
For me, right from early childhood, as I said
before, you know, consciousness isn't something
we have, it's what we and the whole world are.
Many different levels of awareness, many different
levels of perception, many different scales
of perception.
So for me, my whole life has been an exploration
of those different levels, you know, an exploration
of the nature of reality at whatever level
I've been fortunate enough to be able to access
and perceive and communicate with.
And the universe as a whole being interconnected
consciously, like a giant hologram, we're
talking about trillions and trillions of planetary
systems, star systems and potential life forms.
Even though they may be separated from us by thousands and thousands of light years,
through consciousness, that connection can be instantaneous.
Indeed.
Indeed.
That's our universe and, you know, the real, the
leading edge, but there's a really exponentially
growing body of evidence at all scales and at many, many different fields of research
that this is the case, that our universe exists
and evolves as a finite, unified entity within
the infinity of cosmic mind.
Do you sometimes find yourself overwhelmed by the knowledge of all this?
I say fully whelmed, quite overwhelmed,
teetering on the edge of overwhelm sometimes.
But it's, you know, this is over 60 years of exploration, you know, through science,
through, you know, being in international
business and being very grounded through all
of that route, through ancient understanding,
archaeology, all these threads and experiences
have been a progressive journey.
So some of that journey has been a big leap and some of it's been baby steps and some
of it's sort of turned on a, turned round and gone, you know, the wrong way, or not
the wrong way, but, you know, a side avenue.
So it's been all of this journey to this point and beyond.
Now, as an archaeologist, one of your areas of focus has been the creation myths, as I
understand it, of ancient people and how those
myths seem to be in accordance with what we
now know scientifically.
Well some are, some are, not everyone are, but some of the deeper ones.
For example, the ancient Vedic traditions
of India are very profound insights into the
nature of reality and others too.
And it's not just the creation myths that was the basis of my doctorate thesis.
It was how people in ancient times perceived themselves and the cosmos.
So what was their cosmology, not just the creation, but what was their relationship
with the cosmos.
So I've been very fortunate to have many, many experiences with wisdom keepers from
many traditions and also insights and archaeological perspectives.
For example, why people built monuments.
You know, I live in England, very near to a place called Avebury and Stonehenge.
I've been there.
Thousands of, as you know, thousands of years
ago and elsewhere, people were monumentalizing
the landscape, perhaps to connect heaven and earth through human experience.
So it's all of that.
How do we perceive ourselves?
How do we perceive our relationships with each other and the whole world?
And it seems to me that's one of the most
important functions of cosmology is how does
the human individual, presumably or apparently
or mistakenly isolated, fit into the universe
as a whole?
Exactly.
And that requires us to actually bring consciousness
into the very heart of this because mainstream
science for a long time, and it's still to some degree, trying to, well, first of all,
trying to understand consciousness, but perceiving
it in a very duality-based way so that somehow
consciousness or mind arises from matter, what
we're on the threshold now of understanding
that mind is matter.
And so consciousness is absolutely crucial to
our understanding of the nature of reality.
Well, Jude Kuravayan, we've covered a lot of ground here, and I could ask many, many
questions.
I know we can go in a lot of different directions.
Well, one point before we conclude our interview,
let's talk about Gaia, the Earth itself.
I know that this is very important in many of the original peoples of the Earth.
They have a close connection to the planet.
Some even Western philosophers, I think, such
as Leibniz, felt that the Earth is alive.
Again, I feel we need to expand our perception
of what living is beyond biology, and a friend
of mine, Dwayne Elgin, wrote a beautiful book
called The Living Universe, and we describe
ourselves as biocosmic beings in that sense.
So Gaia was the name given to the Earth goddess
by the ancient Greeks, and in modern times,
it started to come forward as a hypothesis by a researcher called James Lovelock who
perceived the Earth as a homeostatic system
where everything is interconnected and relates
to everything else to allow life, biological
life, to emerge and to be nurtured over the
last four, four and a half billion years.
And I write about this in The Cosmic Hologram
because the nature of information, not as
random data but as patterned in formation, in hyphen formation, in forming the world
is very clear in the way that Gaia operates, as it were.
And so this understanding is really emergent
now, and it's emergent in a very important
respect in that we, in my view, need to heal
our relationship, not just with each other
but with Gaia, literally as Mother Earth, our planetary mother who we depend on for
everything.
And we've trashed her and we've polluted her and we've treated her very, very badly,
probably, in my view certainly, because of
our misunderstanding of the nature of reality.
We've seen her as separate, and we need now to
understand that we are intimately interconnected
with her health is our health.
Our well-being is her well-being.
Do you experience Gaia as a conscious entity?
Yes, in different ways than I experience you
as a conscious entity, but nonetheless, you
know, given that very broad definition that I have of consciousness, that it isn't what
we have, it's what we and the whole world are, yes indeed, I do.
And I feel that regardless of whether others
do to that degree, that as a species it is
absolutely vital that we heal our relationship
with her and actually perceiving her as a
living being, perceiving her as a benevolent
mother on whom we depend, even if that's not
that full communion, is an enormous step forward
in how we treat her, how we are with her,
and how we then transform our behaviors with regard to her.
You spoke about understanding Gaia as a conscious
entity, but different from Jeffrey as a conscious
entity.
I did an interview on panpsychism once with a philosopher, Christian de Quincey, and he
made a point of focusing on what he called the holes, meaning holistic, that a planet
or an animal or a human, we are holes, and
so we have a conscious self, whereas perhaps
this lovely statue is an aggregate rather
than a whole, and the statue may not possess
a self in the same way that a human does.
I think that's a fair point.
I think though, from what I was saying earlier,
I don't want to impose my perspectives on
anyone else.
What I'm offering is an invitation to continue
our journey as a species from duality-based
to unity-based awareness, and then different
folks will have different perceptions, but
the perceptions will instead of being perhaps
that they might see the statue as separate
or Jeffrey separate from Jude, that they will
learn to understand experience and body, the
unified reality of which we're all a part, and
yet the individuation, the wonderful abundant
multidimensional diverse realization of that.
Beautifully put.
I couldn't agree more.
So we could have unity and plurality.
Yes, unity and diversity, that's the whole thing.
It's not homogeneity, it's this amazing heterogeneity, abundance, diversity.
Abundance is never bored, because nothing's ever the same.
It's different, it's diverse, it's differentiated.
Jude Currivan, thank you so much for sharing this with me.
It's been a great pleasure.
Thank you, Jeff.
Thank you so much.
I hope you come back often.
I'll be delighted to.
And thank you for being with us as well.
